title: GAGNN: a geography-aware graph neural network for citywide commuting flows prediction
abstract:
•Developed a dual-adjacency attention mechanism integrating geographic and semantic connectivity. •Proposed a Geography-Aware Graph Neural Network (GAGNN) for urban commuting flow prediction. •Established a Comparative Analysis Framework for the Semantic Adjacency Effects of Multi-Source Transportation Networks. •Validated the model on Fuzhou City data, improving MAE, CPC, and prediction accuracy. 
 Urban commuting flow prediction is crucial for optimizing public transportation and improving efficiency, yet traditional models often focus on geographic adjacency, overlooking the complex cross-regional interactions within transportation networks. To address this, we propose a Geography-Aware Graph Neural Network (GAGNN) model for commuting flow prediction. The model first jointly encodes the geographic adjacency matrix and semantic adjacency from public transportation networks, developing a comprehensive attention mechanism to fuse regional proximity with cross-regional semantic connectivity. Subsequently, a Graph Attention Network (GAT) is employed to embed the multiple adjacency relations and multi-source geographic knowledge. Finally, graph embeddings are combined with spatial factors into multidimensional feature vectors, fed into an MLP for commuting flow prediction. The model was validated with Fuzhou workday mobile phone data from January to February 2023, assessing the impact of semantic adjacency from different transportation networks on performance. The results show that: (1) We proposed the GAGNN outperforms both traditional models and advanced graph neural network models (e.g., GSGNN), reducing MAE by 14.9% and improving CPC by 2.1%; (2) The type of semantic adjacency significantly impacts model prediction accuracy. Road-based semantic connections perform best, especially for long-distance commuting flows, followed by metro and bus semantic connections, while the absence of semantic connections yields the worst performance. (3) Spatial scale significantly affects model prediction performance. Under road-based semantic adjacency, accuracy slightly declines with increasing scale, whereas metro, bus, and non-semantic connections, prediction accuracy improves. These findings offer effective support for accurate regional commuting flow modeling and public transportation networks optimization.

title: Modelling of atmospheric copper, iron, and manganese over Europe
abstract:
•European simulation of Cu, Fe and Mn over Europe. •Road and railway abrasion drive Cu and Fe concentrations. •Combustion processes are important source of Fe and Mn. •Cu Simulations are reliable while Fe and Mn exhibit strong negative biases. 
 Although the adverse health effects of particulate matter (PM) are often considered in terms of mass and particle size, a growing number of studies now focus on new health metrics such as the oxidative potential (OP) of PM, highlighting the role of certain metals, among them copper (Cu), iron (Fe), and manganese (Mn) for their capacity to impact OP levels in ambient air. In this study, we built on a previously-developed European anthropogenic emission inventory for Cu, Fe and Mn to simulate PM10 concentrations of these metals within PM10 during a two-year period with the WRF-CHIMERE chemistry transport model, applying a source-tagging method. We also estimated the contribution of erosion dust (mostly of African origin) and urban dust (mostly road and construction dust) as significant sources for each of these metals.For validation purpose, we compared the simulation results with a large database of measurements collected from various sources and locations. The medians of the fractional mean biases for Cu are close to zero for both rural and urban background sites, indicating that the emission in the inventory adequately represent atmospheric Cu concentrations. However, the biases are highly negative for Fe and Mn in a simulation when only considering anthropogenic emissions. The correlation coefficients obtained for (rural and urban) background stations range from 0.4 to 0.6, with urban sites showing slightly higher correlations for Fe but slightly lower ones for Cu and Mn. The inclusion of desert dust sources improves the correlation for some rural stations, while including local urban dust has a less pronounced effect. However, neither source fully explains the significant biases for Fe and Mn concentrations. Overall, this study calls for further works to try and elucidate the missing sources of Fe and Mn, revisit our previously developed emission inventory, and refine the share of PM resuspension to ambient air concentrations of key metallic compounds.

explanation: 该论文研究的是黄河流域从2000年到2023年气溶胶光学厚度（AOD）的时空变化及其潜在影响因素，这与大气环境遥感技术（如空气质量监测、卫星观测、大气成分分析、气溶胶反演）密切相关。论文中使用了REOF分析、Mann-Kendall检验、HYSPLIT模型等方法来研究AOD的变化，这些方法都是大气环境遥感技术中常用的工具。因此，该论文与大气环境遥感技术密切相关。

title: Aerosol optical depth in the Yellow River Basin during 2000-2023: Spatiotemporal variations and potential impacting factors
abstract:
•An abrupt change transitioning from an increasing to decreasing in 2019. •A pattern of slight increase in the western and decrease in the central–eastern YRB. •Air subsidence under high-pressure control and low PBLH hamper vertical diffusion. •Significant impact of human interventions on AOD change. 
 Air pollution poses a significant environmental risk, necessitating effective mitigation and management strategies. The Yellow River Basin (YRB), being a critical region for air pollution control, as it contains 20 cities with the poorest air quality in China, making it one of the area's most severely affected by smog pollution. Understanding the spatiotemporal variations, extreme events, and abrupt changes in aerosol optical depth (AOD) across the YRB is crucial for optimizing measures for air pollution prevention and control measures. This study employs a comprehensive approach, utilizing Rotated Empirical Orthogonal Function (REOF) analysis, Mann-Kendall tests, HYbrid Single-Particle Lagrangian Integrated Trajectory model (HYSPLIT), and circulation field synthesis to investigate AOD variations across different subregions of the YRB from 2000 to 2023. Result reveals a significant abrupt change in 2019, marking a transition from an increasing to decreasing trend. Regionally, AOD slightly increased in the western part, while notable decrease was observed in the central and eastern parts. Among different pollutants, dust contributed the most to AOD, followed by SO2, SO4, and OC, with sea salt and BC are contributing the least. At the synoptic scale, air masses originating from the eastern regions of YRB contributed to higher AOD values, whereas those from the western contributed to lower values. Furthermore, air subsidence under high–pressure control and low planetary boundary layer height (excluding western YRB) hampered vertical diffusion, and failed to explain observed AOD change, underscoring the substantial influence of human interventions. Anthropogenic emissions and policy interventions are significant drivers of AOD variations, indicating that targeted interventions need to be done to improve the air quality.

title: Comparative Online–offline measurement of airborne toxic VOCs for health risk and source identification in an environmental justice community
abstract:
•Toxic VOCs were measured by online TD-GCMS vs. PTR-QMS and canisters. •Distinct concentration spikes were detected by TD-GCMS near industrial complexes. •Online TD-GCMS demonstrated the advantages of instantaneity and accuracy. •Spikes were used to track emission sources with backward trajectories. 
 Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are hazardous air pollutants with significant environmental justice (EJ) implications for communities located near industrial zones. In this study, we deployed an integrated monitoring framework combining online thermal desorption–gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (TD-GC-MS), proton-transfer-reaction mass spectrometry (PTR-QMS), and targeted offline sampling to characterize toxic VOCs in an EJ community adjacent to two industrial complexes. A total of 86 toxic VOCs were monitored at high temporal resolution over one month, supported by inter-comparison with offline canisters and PTR-QMS validation. Our study underscores the value of real-time plume detection, which is indispensable for two purposes: facilitating source investigation and accurately assessing health risks. Time-resolved measurements revealed frequent episodic plumes that are often missed by offline methods, with benzene, vinyl chloride, and carbon tetrachloride dominating both non-carcinogenic and carcinogenic health burdens. For example, benzene contributed approximately 40–45% of the total cancer risk, followed by vinyl chloride (30–35%) and carbon tetrachloride (15–20%). In contrast, risk estimates based on offline canister data were lower by nearly 50–60%, highlighting the substantial underestimation of episodic exposures when relying on canister sampling. Trajectory analysis linked emission spikes to specific industrial sectors, including textile dyeing, plastics, and solvent use, with sorbent sampling confirming sources. The detection of carbon tetrachloride, a banned ozone-depleting substance, underscores its persistent emissions. This integrated monitoring approach demonstrates the critical role of high-resolution VOC data in health risk assessment, pollution forensics, and targeted mitigation in vulnerable EJ communities.

authors: Yinan Cai;Zesheng Chen;Qiwei Sun;Yan Du
title: Global water cycle changes in a warming climate: Projection from CMIP6 multi-model ensemble mean
abstract:
•Hydrological cycle intensifies under SSP2–4.5 and SSP5–8.5. •Intensification shows pronounced land–ocean asymmetry under warming. •Land precipitation rises ∼1.10–1.40 faster than over oceans. •Ocean-to-land moisture transport increases up to 13.5% by late 21st century. 
 Understanding the response of the global hydrological cycle to anthropogenic warming is critical for advancing water resources management and mitigating hydrological risks. This study employs a multi-model ensemble from the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6) to quantify projected changes in key global hydrological components, including evaporation, precipitation, total column water vapor (TCWV), and ocean-to-land moisture transport, under medium-emission (SSP2–4.5) and high-emission (SSP5–8.5) scenarios. Our analysis demonstrates a robust and progressively intensifying hydrological cycle throughout the 21st century, with substantially stronger changes under SSP5–8.5. Relative to 1995–2014, TCWV increases by 5.5% (2021–2040) and 16.8% (2081–2100) under SSP2–4.5, and by 6.3% and 34.8% under SSP5–8.5. A pronounced land–ocean asymmetry emerges: land regions exhibit more pronounced changes than oceans, with increases in terrestrial precipitation approximately 1.10–1.40 times greater than the corresponding oceanic rates, indicating stronger land amplification. Ocean-to-land moisture transport rises by 6.2% under SSP2–4.5 and 13.5% under SSP5–8.5 by the end of the century, contributing significantly to enhanced land precipitation and highlighting the importance of atmospheric moisture redistribution in shaping continental water availability. This study consolidates the quantitative sensitivity of the global water cycle to emission pathways and provides critical insights to support climate adaptation strategies.

title: Mass absorption efficiency and optical emission assessment of elemental carbon from residential solid fuel combustion
abstract:
•Mass absorption efficiency of element carbon (MAEEC) from residential solid fuel combustion was investigated. •Crop residue burning showed the highest MAEECvalue, followed by coal and wood combustion. •A county-level optical emission inventory of EC was developed for the Guanzhong Plain. 
 The distinctive light-absorption properties of elemental carbon (EC) emitted from solid fuel combustion significantly influence both regional and global climate systems. This study investigated the mass absorption efficiency of EC (MAEEC) at 633 nm wavelength using laboratory-simulated biomass and coal combustion combined with carbon analysis. Diagnostic ratios of carbon components, including EC/PM2.5, organic carbon (OC)/EC, and char-EC/soot-EC, were investigated to characterize the difference in crop residue, wood, and coal combustion emissions. The average MAEEC values varied significantly among fuel types, with crop residue burning showing the highest value (11.2 ± 3.2 m2 g−1), followed by coal combustion (5.5 ± 2.2 m2 g−1) and wood burning (3.0 ± 0.9 m2 g−1). Multiple linear regression analysis revealed that OC/EC ratio was the primary factor influencing MAEEC values, possibly attributed to the lensing effect of OC coating. An optical emission inventory of EC from residential solid fuel combustion in the Guanzhong Plain was further developed using our experimentally determined MAEEC, referenced mass emission factors of EC, and county-level activity data to quantify regional optical impacts. These results should advance the understanding of EC radiative effects from residential solid fuel combustion and provide crucial scientific evidence for developing targeted emission reduction policies.
